title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe the trend in total seafood production in South Korea between 1960 and 1986, such as any the following:

· Production rapidly increased between 1960 and 1986.

· Production of total seafood increased by 9 times from 1960 to 1986.

The response describes the trend in total seafood production in South Korea between 1960 and 1986, such as one the following:

· Production rapidly increased between 1960 and 1986.

· Production of total seafood increased by 9 times from 1960 to 1986.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the year in which seafood production by aquaculture and wild-caught seafood production in South Korea were approximately equal as 2015.
The response identifies the year in which seafood production by aquaculture and wild-caught seafood production in South Korea were approximately equal as 2015.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain one way the change in seafood production may have impacted the South Korean fishing industry’s fuel consumption, such as the following:

· Catching wild fish requires more fuel than aquaculture. As wild-caught seafood production has leveled off and aquaculture has increased, the amount of fuel used to process the same amount of seafood has decreased.

The response explains one way the change in seafood production may have impacted the South Korean fishing industry’s fuel consumption, such as the following:

· Catching wild fish requires more fuel than aquaculture. As wild-caught seafood production has leveled off and aquaculture has increased, the amount of fuel used to process the same amount of seafood has decreased.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim using evidence that supports or refutes the assertion that purchasing farmed trout is a better choice for the environment than purchasing farmed catfish, such as the following:

· Trout are secondary consumers and eat higher on the food chain. This means they require more energy/biomass than primary consumers, which has a greater impact on the environment.

The response makes a claim using evidence that supports or refutes the assertion that purchasing farmed trout is a better choice for the environment than purchasing farmed catfish, such as the following:

· Trout are secondary consumers and eat higher on the food chain. This means they require more energy/biomass than primary consumers, which has a greater impact on the environment.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim by citing an environmental problem associated with one of the options that supports or refutes the assertion that purchasing farmed halibut is a better choice for the environment than purchasing wild-caught halibut, such as any of the following:

Farmed Halibut

· Grown in high population densities and are vulnerable to hosting and spreading diseases and parasites

· Grown in high population densities producing high levels of fish waste which may cause eutrophication from nutrient loading

· Require large amounts of fish meal resulting in overfishing of wild fish to produce fish meal

· Can escape and interbreed with local wild populations decreasing genetic diversity

· Can escape and compete with local wild populations for food and resources

· Excessive antibiotic usage can pollute adjacent waters and lead to an increase in antibiotic resistant bacteria

Wild-caught Halibut

· Fishing methods used to catch halibut catch non-target species like turtles and sea birds which are killed and discarded

· Endanger wild fish stocks and are subject to overfishing

· Fishing boats consume large amounts of fuel resulting in increased levels of sulfur dioxide, particulates, and carbon dioxide emissions

The response makes a claim by citing an environmental problem associated with one of the options that supports or refutes the assertion that purchasing farmed halibut is a better choice for the environment than purchasing wild-caught halibut, such as one of the following:

Farmed Halibut

· Grown in high population densities and are vulnerable to hosting and spreading diseases and parasites

· Grown in high population densities producing high levels of fish waste which may cause eutrophication from nutrient loading

· Require large amounts of fish meal resulting in overfishing of wild fish to produce fish meal

· Can escape and interbreed with local wild populations decreasing genetic diversity

· Can escape and compete with local wild populations for food and resources

· Excessive antibiotic usage can pollute adjacent waters and lead to an increase in antibiotic resistant bacteria

Wild-caught Halibut

· Fishing methods used to catch halibut catch non-target species like turtles and sea birds which are killed and discarded

· Endanger wild fish stocks and are subject to overfishing

· Fishing boats consume large amounts of fuel resulting in increased levels of sulfur dioxide, particulates, and carbon dioxide emissions

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not propose a solution to the environmental problem cited in part (e), such as any of the following:

Grown in high population densities and are vulnerable to hosting and spreading diseases and parasites or grown in high population densities producing high levels of fish waste which may cause eutrophication from nutrient loading (problem in part (e)).

· Administer medication to protect them from disease

· Use larger enclosures out to sea/stock fewer fish to reduce densities, reduce stocking density, and/or increase the flow of fresh seawater to reduce disease transmission and nutrient loading

Require large amounts of fish meal resulting in overfishing of wild fish to produce fish meal (problem in part (e)).

· Switch to more plant-based proteins derived from soy

Can escape and interbreed with local wild populations decreasing genetic diversity or can escape and compete with local wild populations for food and resources(problem in part (e)).

· Build more resilient escape-proof containment systems around the pens

Fishing methods used to catch halibut catch non-target species like turtles and sea birds which are killed and discarded (problem in part (e)).

· Modify fishing equipment and practices to customize them for halibut

· Require reporting of bycatch to keep below a quota/limit

Endanger wild fish stocks and are subject to overfishing (problem in part (e)).

· Enforce strict quotas are limits on the number amount of fish that can be caught

· Avoid catching young fish before reproductive age

Fishing boats consume large amounts of fuel resulting in increased levels of sulfur dioxide, particulates, and carbon dioxide emissions (problem in part (e)).

· Switch to lower emission, cleaner burning fuel like liquified natural gas

The response proposes a solution to the environmental problem cited in part (e), such as one of the following:

Grown in high population densities and are vulnerable to hosting and spreading diseases and parasites or grown in high population densities producing high levels of fish waste which may cause eutrophication from nutrient loading (problem in part (e)).

· Administer medication to protect them from disease

· Use larger enclosures out to sea/stock fewer fish to reduce densities, reduce stocking density, and/or increase the flow of fresh seawater to reduce disease transmission and nutrient loading

Require large amounts of fish meal resulting in overfishing of wild fish to produce fish meal (problem in part (e)).

· Switch to more plant-based proteins derived from soy

Can escape and interbreed with local wild populations decreasing genetic diversity or can escape and compete with local wild populations for food and resources(problem in part (e)).

· Build more resilient escape-proof containment systems around the pens

Fishing methods used to catch halibut catch non-target species like turtles and sea birds which are killed and discarded (problem in part (e)).

· Modify fishing equipment and practices to customize them for halibut

· Require reporting of bycatch to keep below a quota/limit

Endanger wild fish stocks and are subject to overfishing (problem in part (e)).

· Enforce strict quotas are limits on the number amount of fish that can be caught

· Avoid catching young fish before reproductive age

Fishing boats consume large amounts of fuel resulting in increased levels of sulfur dioxide, particulates, and carbon dioxide emissions (problem in part (e)).

· Switch to lower emission, cleaner burning fuel like liquified natural gas

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one disadvantage or unintended consequence that could result from the solution proposed in part (f), such as any of the following:

Administer medication to protect them from disease (solution in part (f)).

· Increases the concentration of pharmaceuticals in the environment

· Increases the possibility of organisms evolving resistance

Switch to more plant-based proteins derived from soy (solution in part (f)).

· Environmental problems associated with growing soy include, slash-and burn agriculture, synthetic fertilizer and pesticide use.

· Increased demand on food crops for use as animal feed reduces availability for human consumption and increases food insecurity

Use larger enclosures further out to sea/stock fewer fish to reduce population density and increase the flow of fresh seawater to reduce disease transmission (solution in part (f)).

· More fuel will be required to service the enclosures.

· Could be more susceptible to damage from storms

· Yield will decrease

Modify longlining equipment and practices to customize them for halibut (solution in part (f)).

· May be expensive to modify equipment

· Production may decrease

Enforce strict quotas ore limits on the number amount of fish that can be caught or avoid catching young fish before reproductive age (solution in part (f)).

· Additional cost of enforcing regulations requires additional regulators and monitoring

· Economic impact of quotas on fishermen

Switch to lower emission, cleaner burning fuel like liquified natural gas (solution in part (f)).

· Expense of switching to new technology

· Could decrease the range of the boat

· It could be difficult to get fuel

Build more resilient escape-proof containment systems around the pens (solution in part (f)).

· Costs increase significantly; make farming unprofitable

The response describes one disadvantage or unintended consequence that could result from the solution proposed in part (f), such as one of the following:

Administer medication to protect them from disease (solution in part (f)).

· Increases the concentration of pharmaceuticals in the environment

· Increases the possibility of organisms evolving resistance

Switch to more plant-based proteins derived from soy (solution in part (f)).

· Environmental problems associated with growing soy include, slash-and burn agriculture, synthetic fertilizer and pesticide use.

· Increased demand on food crops for use as animal feed reduces availability for human consumption and increases food insecurity

Use larger enclosures further out to sea/stock fewer fish to reduce population density and increase the flow of fresh seawater to reduce disease transmission (solution in part (f)).

· More fuel will be required to service the enclosures.

· Could be more susceptible to damage from storms

· Yield will decrease

Modify longlining equipment and practices to customize them for halibut (solution in part (f)).

· May be expensive to modify equipment

· Production may decrease

Enforce strict quotas ore limits on the number amount of fish that can be caught or avoid catching young fish before reproductive age (solution in part (f)).

· Additional cost of enforcing regulations requires additional regulators and monitoring

· Economic impact of quotas on fishermen

Switch to lower emission, cleaner burning fuel like liquified natural gas (solution in part (f)).

· Expense of switching to new technology

· Could decrease the range of the boat

· It could be difficult to get fuel

Build more resilient escape-proof containment systems around the pens (solution in part (f)).

· Costs increase significantly; make farming unprofitable

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe an environmental problem that was the result of public ownership of the resource, such as any of the following:

· When the freely available resource is acquired by an individual, it becomes their property. This encourages them to take more than their “fair” share of this “free” resource and a Tragedy of the Commons results.

· When individuals use shared resources, they often use with regard to their own self-interest rather than for the common good, which can deplete the resource.

· When undesired goods or pollution are deposited in a “sink” the disposal cost is near zero. This encourages the disposal of more than a “fair” share into this “free” sink and a Tragedy of the Commons results.

The response describes an environmental problem that was the result of public ownership of the resource, such as one of the following:

· When the freely available resource is acquired by an individual, it becomes their property. This encourages them to take more than their “fair” share of this “free” resource and a Tragedy of the Commons results.

· When individuals use shared resources, they often use with regard to their own self-interest rather than for the common good, which can deplete the resource.

· When undesired goods or pollution are deposited in a “sink” the disposal cost is near zero. This encourages the disposal of more than a “fair” share into this “free” sink and a Tragedy of the Commons results.
